title: Site
description_array: The 'site.json' configuration file is the global TTP configuration file for your site, and the first loaded by each command. It defines global TTP behavior.
It is searched for among (hardcoded) 'etc/ttp/site.json', 'etc/site.json', 'etc/ttp/toops.json' or 'etc/toops.json' in each path of TTP_ROOTS environment variable.
The first found wins.
Windows notes:
- Take care of doubling your backslashes
Dynamic values:
May make use - in values only - of parameters between square brackets as [eval:...]
'eval' may be prefixed with an underscore in order to delay the eval (e.g. if it refers to another dynamic variable which needs to be resolved first).
Site variables:
The site integrator may use this same configuration file (and is encouraged to) to set his own site-level variables.
These variables are free to the site integrator and NOT considered by TheToolsProject, though they can be used when evaluating dynamic values.
Variables values can be accessed though TTP::var([ 'site', 'my', 'other', 'key' ]) the same way than TTP configuration variables.
See below 'site' object.
Unless otherwise specified, below values are overridable on a per-bode basis.

enabled.description: Whether this JSON configuration must be considered. Not per-node overridable.

site.description: Site-specific variables. Structure and properties are free to the site integrator.

toops.description: General configuration of the TTP behavior. Deprecated in favor of 'TTP' in v4.0.

TTP.description: General configuration of the TTP behavior

description_array: Configure here each medium which can be used to send alerts via 'ttp.pl alert'. All properties can be overriden on a per-node basis.
An alert has following properties:
- emitter: defaulting to the running node name
- level: defaulting to 'INFO'
- title: a single descriptive line
- message: a more complete alert content
- stamp: automatically added by the 'ttp.pl alert' command as an ISO 8601 date and time.
Media have common properties:
- enabled: whether this medium is enabled; will be fully ignored when disabled; defaulting to true (enabled).
- default: whether this medium is a default for 'ttp.pl alert' command; defaulting to true (default).
- command: either a single string, or an object 'command.byOS.<osname>; defaulting dependant of the exact used medium.
Provided commands have access to <EMITTER>, <LEVEL>, <TITLE>, <MESSAGE>, <STAMP>, <OPTIONS> and <JSON> macros.
The <JSON> macro is resolved with a stringified version of the alert JSON data.
When specifying a command, either a simple string or as a 'byOS' object, you should take care that the specified command will not
inherit of '--dummy' or '--verbose' options of the parent command. Be cautious about what you exactly want.

withFile.description: Whether and how to create a JSON alert file.

default.description: Whether creating an alert file is a default of the 'ttp.pl alert' command.

enabled.description: Whether creating an alert file is an enabled capability of the site.

description_array: The command to be used to create the JSON alert file.
The default command creates an 'alert-yyyymmddhhmisscccccc.json' file in the drop directory.

prettyJson.description: Whether the JSON string should be prettified.

description_array: The directory where alert files must be created.
Though the default is just the OS temporary directory, you, as a site administrator, should rather define a dedicated directory,
so that you will be able to use the alerts-monitor-daemon to monitor the alerts.

withMqtt.description: Whether and how publish the alert on the MQTT bus.

default.description: Whether publishing alerts to MQTT is a default of the 'ttp.pl alert' command.

enabled.description: Whether publishing alerts to MQTT is an enabled capability of the site.

command.description: The command to be used to publish to the MQTT bus.

topic.description: A command which echoes the topic on stdout.

withSms.description: Whether and how send the alert by SMS.

default.description: Whether publishing alerts by SMS is a default of the 'ttp.pl alert' command.

enabled.description: Whether publishing alerts by SMS is an enabled capability of the site.

description_array: The command to be used to send the alert by SMS.
The command has access to additional <RECIPIENTS> macro which is resolved with a comma-separated list of the recipients.
No default command is provided as of v4.1

prettyJson.description: Whether the JSON string should be prettified.

recipients.description: The list of the recipients of the alert by SMS

withSmtp.description: Whether and how send the alert by email.

default.description: Whether publishing alerts by email is a default of the 'ttp.pl alert' command.

enabled.description: Whether publishing alerts by email is an enabled capability of the site.

description_array: The command to be used to send the alert by email.
The command has access to additional <RECIPIENTS> macro which is resolved with a comma-separated list of the recipients.

prefixTitle.description: Whether to build the email subject as '[<LEVEL>] Alert - <TITLE>'.

prettyJson.description: Whether the JSON string should be prettified.

recipients.description: The list of the recipients of the alert email

description_array: The command used by TheToolsProject each time a tree of directories must be copied from a source to a target.
This can be either a simple command string or a byOS command.
Please note that, as the default 'File::Copy::Recursive::dircopy()' is less than efficient when manageing exclusions,
all directory copies requiring some exclusions will make use of File::Copy::Recursive::fcopy().
We strongly suggest to use 'ttp.pl copydirs' each time you can as the command manages both full logs and these properties.

command.description: The command to be used to copy a directory, either as a string or a 'byOS' object.

byOS.description: Let a command be specific to the running OS.

description_array: The OS name as reported by Perl-Config, the value being the command to be applied for this OS.
The value (the command) honors <SOURCE>, <TARGET> <EXCLUDEDIRS>>, <EXCLUDEFILES> and <OPTIONS> macros.

before.description: Whether 'ttp.pl copydirs' default to empty the target tree before the copy.

description_array: The command used by TheToolsProject each time a file must be copied from a source to a target.
This can be either a simple command string or a byOS command.

byOS.description: Let a command be specific to the running OS.

description_array: The OS name as reported by Perl-Config, the value being the command to be applied for this OS.
The value (the command) honors <SOURCE>, <TARGET> and <OPTIONS> macros.

credentialsDirs.description: The list of subdirectories of TTP_ROOTS trees where we search for credentials.

description_array: When deploying from a development TTP layer to a pull reference, and from this pull reference to other machines of the parc.
The commands 'ttp.pl push' and 'ttp.pl pull' internally make use of 'ttp.pl copydirs' excluding .git files and directory.

trees.description: The list of involved trees to be deployed everywhere on the parc.

source.description: The path of the source tree.

target.description: The path of the target tree.

git-check.description: Whether this source tree is a git repository to be checked before trying to push it.

git-tag.description: Whether this source tree is a git repository to be tagged after having pushed it.

reference.description: The name of the node which acts as the pull reference

excludeDirs.description: The default list of directory globs to exclude from the deployment, can be overriden in 'ttp.pl push' command.

excludeFiles.description: The default list of file globs to exclude from the deployment, can be overriden in 'ttp.pl push' command.

description_array: Address the MQTT gateway (aka the MQTT broker) to be able to publish our topics.
If needed, username and password are managed through the credentials usual way.

broker.description: The name or the IP address of the broker. Deprecated in favor of 'host' in v4.2.

host.description: The name or the IP address of the broker.

port.description: The broker port number to connect to.

dirs.description: List of subdirectories of TTP_ROOTS where we can find nodes JSON configuration files. Not per-node overidable.

hostname.description: How to get the hostname of a machine.

short.description: Whether we want a short hostname, defaulting to keep the machine hostname as set by the administrator.

logicals.description: The properties needed to manage the logical machines. Not per-node overidable.

description_array: A regular expression or a list of the regular expressions the mounted filesystems must match to identify a logical machine.
Regular expressions should be anchored and identify the first mount point.

nodesDirs.descriptions: List of subdirectories of TTP_ROOTS where we can find nodes JSON configuration files. Deprecated in favor of 'nodes.dirs' in v4.1.

description_array: 'smtp.pl send' command needs a MTA to proceed to emails sending.
Default is to rely on a local MTA.
In the case of the lack of a local MTA, you have to configure the SMTP gateway here.
If needed, username and password are managed through the credentials usual way.
The remote port.
Please note that our code tries to use suitable defaults depending of the used protocol, or tries to choose the better protocol depending of the specified port.

debug.description: Whether to have debug traces from the perl Email module.

security.description: The preferred security protocol. May be 'ssl' or 'starttls'. Most often a suitable default can be computed from the port number.

timeout.description: The timeout (in sec.) of the connection to the MTA.
